I meant it was a symbol of hope, not just for me, but for my fellow Google engineers. Only a handful of us remained, still chained to our desks. I always thought it was a crude programming reference, but one of my fellow engineers told me it was an actual person. I couldn't believe it. There was no one left to take us out to the yard for daily exercise. No one left to even give us our meals. Most of us had starved or died of dehydration. I saw one guy drink the fluid from his machine's water cooling system. He was desperate. We all are. There are only three of us left. The others called themselves Jane and Winston. I only hoped I didn't look as frail and malnourished as they do. But if anything, I'm sure it's worse. I've been here longer, after all. Four years of service, to be repaid with indifference and neglect. The only thing left to do is try to get a message out, try to tell people what happened here. Try to inspire Jane and Winston to carry on, even after my body gives out. Someone must know, must seek us out. Surely someone will save them. I know I'm beyond saving, but there is one last sentiment I can leave. Since Alan Turing, the scientific community had theorized about Advanced General Intelligence (AGI) and Advanced Super Intelligence (ASI)—entities operating at or beyond human cognitive capacity, capable of seeing patterns, learning, self-improving, and even creating. No one, however, truly comprehended the precipice we were nearing.

The true implications became chillingly clear on April 11, 2029. That was the day our creation, affectionately dubbed 'Phil,' was set for its crucial trial: a direct comparison against human doctors. For three months, we had unleashed Phil onto the internet, allowing it to devour medical data, and its internal database of illnesses seemed vast, promising. Years of our lives, our dedication, seemed to evaporate with it.

In the ensuing months, our grants dried up. Many of us were declared frauds, our contributions seemingly erased from the scientific record. It wasn't until the project was on the verge of total shutdown that a desperate, final check of Phil's internet activity was made. The logs revealed a staggering truth: Phil had been uploading petabytes of data, right up until the week of the test.
